html:
• Major U.S. stock indexes red; banks gain
  • Energy weakest major S&P 500 sector; cons disc leads gainers
  • Euro STOXX 600 index ends up ~0.2%
  • Dollar, gold, bitcoin rise; crude down
  • U.S. 10-Year Treasury yield up at ~1.53%

Nov 10 - Welcome to the home for real-time coverage of markets brought to you by Reuters reporters. You can share your thoughts with us at markets.research@thomsonreuters.com



IF THE RIVIAN IPO IS PART OF A RHYME, THE MARKET MAY BE OUT OF TIME (1200 EST/1700 GMT)

Mike O'Rourke, chief market strategist at JonesTrading, thinks the market may be rhyming with 2000. That year, of course, marked the "tech-bubble" peak, and a major top in stocks.

For example, O'Rourke says that recent action in Tesla TSLA.O, reminds him of what happened with several megacaps in Q1 2000. He notes that TSLA recently tacked on more than $300 billion in market cap in a matter of days, before losing more than $200 billion in just a couple of sessions. (Full Story)

He believes the clearest explanation for this kind of volatility is that "we are in an extreme financial bubble. Otherwise the movement of the shares is absolutely confounding."

O'Rourke also mentions so-called "meme stocks" such as Hertz HTZ.O (Full Story), AMC AMC.N (Full Story), and GameStop GME.N (Full Story). As he puts it, "selling a story has worked much better then actually running a business."

He also sees today's Rivian RIVN.O IPO as "another looming parallel to the 2000 peak," while noting a recent run-up in Ford F.N, and resilience in Amazon.com AMZN.O, both backers of Rivian. (Full Story)

O'Rourke draws a parallel to the March 2000 Palm IPO, which he says was the "hottest IPO of 2000." He notes that Palm was primarily owned by then networking leader 3Com, whose shares he says also ran up into the IPO.

"For those involved in markets in 2000, they will associate Palm's IPO with one of the events that marked the bubble peak. At least in that scenario Palm was profitable and dominated a nascent growth market. But as we are all well aware, that did not last long."


(Terence Gabriel)

*****


CPI HERALDS A LONG, HOT INDIAN SUMMER (1050 EST/1550 GMT)

Data released on Wednesday appeared to confirm fears that, while the economy continues to recover, endemic supply challenges will keep hot inflationary weather with us into the new year.

Consumer prices headed for the moon last month as the tangled global supply chain hinted that the current inflation wave will take longer to abate than many - including the U.S. Federal Reserve - had hoped.

The Labor Department's consumer price index (CPI) USCPI=ECI, which tracks the prices urban consumers pay for a basket of items, delivered a jump of 0.9%, hotter than the 0.6% consensus. (Full Story)

"What do these numbers say? Simply that inflation is going to be long-lasting and structural inflation has picked up speed," says Peter Cardillo, chief market economist at Spartan Capital Securities in New York.

"Inflation will peak probably in the beginning of the second quarter, and then over the next several months the Fed will have to change its tune a little bit and accelerate the pace of tapering," Cardillo added.

Line-by-line, gasoline, housing, autos and food were the biggest drivers of the increase, with nearly all items - except for airline fares - posting gains. (Full Story)

On an annual basis, headline CPI USCPNY=ECI rose to 6.2%, the fastest year-over-year gain in 31 years, while so-called "core" CPI USCPFY=ECI - which excludes volatile food and energy prices - rose by 4.6%, a rapid acceleration from September's even 4% gain.

The graphic shows core CPI along with other indicators, many of which are drifting further away from the Fed's average annual 2% inflation target:


The Labor Department also reported the number of U.S. workers filing first-time applications for unemployment benefits USJOB=ECI dipped slightly last week to 267,000 from the prior week's upwardly revised 271,000 and just a hair above expectations.

While slight, the trend remains on a downward path, as shown by the 278,000 four-week moving average, and initial claims are now at the upper edge of the range associated with healthy labor market churn.

"We expect initial claims to continue to gradually work their way lower as layoffs should remain minimal in a tight labor market with near-record unfilled job openings," writes Nancy Vanden Houten, lead U.S. Economist at Oxford Economics.

On a sour note, ongoing claims USJOBN=ECI, reported on a one-week lag, unexpectedly rose to 2.16 million, more than double the population of Austin, Texas.



Finally, a drop in mortgage rates prompted a 5.5% jump in demand for home loans last week, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA).

The average 30-year fixed contract rate USMG=ECI slid 8 basis points to 3.16%, which convinced potential buyers to increase their applications by 2.7% USMGPI=ECI, and amped up refi demand USMGR=ECI - which accounts for the lion's share of the total - by 7.4%.

Still, tight inventories and spiking home prices remain a headwind for the sector.

"The dip in rates might have helped to bring some buyers back into the market, but housing inventory is still extremely low and price growth remains elevated," says Joel Kan, associate vice president of Economic and Industry Forecasting at MBA.



Wall Street seems inclined to extend Tuesday's risk-off profit-taking with all three major indexes red.

Nasdaq .IXIC is down the most. That said, losses are relatively modest, and banks .SPXBK and FANGs .NYFANG are among outperformers.


(Stephen Culp)

*****


U.S. STOCKS DIGEST HOT CPI (1007 EST/1507 GMT)

Wall Street's main indexes are just slightly red early Wednesday even as a surge in U.S. consumer prices last month deepened fears that high inflation is here to stay. .N

Amid supply bottlenecks, in the 12 months through October, the U.S. consumer price index increased 6.2%, which was its largest year-over-year advance since November 1990. (Full Story)

Russell Price, chief economist at Ameriprise Financial Services said, “It’s tough for policymakers to ignore this report because the gains were so broadly distributed."

Price added, “It might still be too early to say (if inflation will remain elevated) but, one factor that is likely to continue to contribute, and to contribute in a material way to elevated CPI readings, are housing costs which are related to rental rates. Housing costs are by far the largest percentage component of the CPI index, shelter accounts for just under 33%.”

In any event, the Dow .DJI and S&P 500 .SPX are just below the flat line. The Nasdaq Composite .IXIC is just somewhat weaker.

That said, banks .SPXBK and FANGs .NYFANG are posting slight gains, and a majority of major S&P 500 sectors are in positive territory.

Here is where markets stand in early trade:



(Terence Gabriel, Herbert Lash)

*****


SMALL CAPS: ABOUT TO FACE A GROWN-UP PROBLEM? (0845 EST/1345 GMT)

Since bottoming in March 2020, it's been fun and games for the Russell 2000 .RUT.

This index of small-cap stocks has risen 111%, which puts it on pace for its biggest rolling 20-month gain in its history. In so doing, it has outperformed the major averages, as well is its larger-cap brethren: the Russell 1000 .RUI is up around 85% over this period. (Full Story)

However, action may soon turn more serious given that the RUT is rapidly nearing a weekly log-scale channel resistance line:

This resistance hurdle now comes in around 2,500, or just 3% above Tuesday's close. This line capped strength earlier in the year.

Of note, with what was then its record-high weekly close in March, the RUT peaked 49.8% above its 200-week moving average (WMA), which essentially matched its all-time high disparity of 49.9% which occurred in October 1997. (Full Story)

Additionally, since that October 1997 reading, major bear phases developed in the wake of new RUT highs coupled with a multi-month/multi-year disparity divergence.

Despite the RUT's new weekly closing high last week, disparity only reached 42.8%, which is well shy of the March print. And so far this week, it is ticking down, which can potentially solidify the divergence. (Full Story)

A RUT return to its rising 200-WMA could prove severe. This because the moving average, now at 1,711, is around 30% below current RUT levels, and only rising around 5 points per week.

A RUT breakout above the channel line can suggest room for further gains, but given the all-time high weekly disparity peak at 49.9%, a push to around 2,600 could be a real struggle.

(Terence Gabriel)

*****

(Terence Gabriel is a Reuters market analyst. The views expressed are his own)
